revised_title: Programmed Cell Death and Undead Cells in Caenorhabditis elegans
tldr: The article discusses the process of programmed cell death in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans and the role of genes ced-3 and ced-4 in initiating cell death. Mutations in these genes can lead to "undead" cells that survive and are incorporated into the adult organism without any negative consequences. The study examines the nature of these undead cells, their similarities and differences, and their potential to replace functioning neurons in the nervous system.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Developmental Biology
